A pain score of 4-7 indicates severe pain, and a pain score of 8-10 indicates very severe pain. Hydromorphone is a synthetic opioid that is 3 times more potent than morphine. It is commonly used in the management of moderate to severe pain due to its potency and long duration of action. Hydromorphone is given intravenously (IV) and can also be given subcutaneously or intramuscularly. The recommended dose for intravenous hydromorphone is 0.1–0.2 mg per kilogram (kg) of body weight every 15 min as needed, with a maximum recommended dose of 10 mg per dose. For moderate to severe pain, the recommended dose is 0.1 mg/kg every 15 min as needed, with a maximum recommended dose of 8 mg per dose. For mild to moderate pain, the recommended dose is 0.01–0.05 mg/kg every 15 min as needed, with a maximum recommended dose of 1 mg per dose. For mild pain, the recommended dose is 0.01 mg/kg every 15 min as needed, with a maximum recommended dose of 1 mg per dose. For opioid-naïve patients, the dose should be reduced by 30%. Hydromorphone should be used with caution in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), asthma, or other respiratory disorders, as hydromorphone can cause respiratory depression. Hydromorphone can also cause constipation, which can be life-threatening in patients with an intestinal obstruction. Hydromorphone should be used with caution in patients with renal impairment, as hydromorphone is metabolized by the kidneys. Hydromorphone can also cause severe itching, nausea, vomiting, and sweating. Hydromorphone is contraindicated in patients with a history of hypersensitivity to hydromorphone or other opioids. Hydromorphone is also contraindicated in patients with acute alcohol intoxication, acute or chronic alcoholism, and drug-induced respiratory depression. Hydromorphone should be used with caution in patients with prolonged QT interval, protracted QT interval, and a history of cardiovascular disease. Hydromorphone is also contraindicated in patients with paralytic ileus. Hydromorphone is considered a Schedule II controlled substance.
